intro: Rhus succedanea var. longipes, commonly known as the smooth sumac, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its compound leaves, which are pinnately arranged and turn vibrant red in the fall. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers in upright clusters, followed by red, fuzzy berries that are a food source for birds. Its bark is smooth and grayish, and it thrives in full sun to partial shade in well-drained soils. It is often used in landscaping for its ornamental value and ability to tolerate various environmental conditions.
